loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is a widower with three children to look after. He says being a widower is more difficult than being a bachelor. The death of his supportive wife left him saddened. He has had to start doing some of those things his wife did that  he had taken for granted. Challenged by these realities he has doubled his effort towards meeting the needs of his children. This made him  join GHAPE in early part of 2006. With his first loan he bought palm nuts for processing as he already had an oil mill. The demand for palm oil is very high now and people come from neighboring communities to buy oil from him. Relying on one oil mill is not enough as it sometimes get bad and may take some time to be repaired.

Given a loan of $300, George plans to buy another small oil mill in order to increase his production. His community will have good palm oil for cooking and stands a chance of benefiting from his activities as he will have to employ somebody to work with the mill because he cannot work with both machines by himself. He plans to repay the loan during the loan term

loans.use: purchase of a palm oil mill.

loans.name: Margaret Bih.

texts.en:
Margaret is one of several wives and mother of nine children. She is not only challenged to live with mates but also to live with daily quarrellings between her children and those of her mates. In most polygamist's homes each woman has to fend for herself and her children. This is the situation in which Margaret finds herself. She says sometimes she feels mal-treated and  has to work very hard to meet her needs. Out of desperation she started planting flowers as a way of keeping herself busy. But soon the population started requesting  them. 
 
Given a loan of $100, Margaret plans to buy polythene bags and flower seeds to increase her production of fresh flowers for sale. Her garden is situated at a road junction and there are a lot of admirers and customers. Her flower garden beautifies the scenery of her community and is a source of attraction for many people. She intends to use profit to pay tuition for her children and for buying food.

loans.use: Purchase of polythene bags and flower seeds.

loans.name: Ibadet

texts.en:
Ibadet M. is 43-year-old married man who is the owner of a flock of sheep. He is from Mazrali village near IMishli town, situated in the southern part of Azerbaijan.

Ibadet has a big family, a wife and three children. He started his business in 1999. With money he had saved up, he purchased 10 sheep to raise for resale. Mutton is in high demand in Azerbaijan, and his business brought him income. He enlarged his flock from ten to twenty, and now he wants to purchase some goats and additional sheep.

Since the autumn and winter is high season for purchasing mutton, Yadigar decided to borrow US$ 1200 to buy fifteen additional sheep (at about US$ 70 each), and six goats (at about US$ 30 each).

loans.use: purchase 15 sheep and 6 goats

loans.name: Rafiqa

texts.en:
Rafiqa Q. is a 51-year-old married woman. She was born and lives in Otuzik village near Imishli town, situated in the southern part of Azerbaijan. She started her business in 2002 when economic conditions in her family were very bad.

Rafiqa has three children and to cover their needs she purchased one milk cow. Later, she started to sell milk and yoghurt to local people. These milk products are in very high demand in her region. Rafiqa improved her family's living conditions to some extent, and now she has applied for a loan of US$ 900 to purchase another cow for $700 to $750. She plans to use the rest of the money on cattle fodder for the winter.

loans.use: purchase one cow and cattle fodder for winter

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim S. is a 53-year-old married man who has three children. He is a farmer in Varkhankend Village near Imishli town, situated in the southern part of Azerbaijan. He started his business in 1999, when he purchased one cow with money he had saved up. He has made very good profit by selling milk products such as yoghurt, sour-cream, and milk. These products are in high demand in his area.

Over the years, life in Azerbaijan has gotten harder and harder and to cover family needs, one cow is not enough. In 2006 Ibrahim borrowed US$ 500 to add to his own savings of $250 and purchased another milk cow. Since January 2007, prices have doubled and Ibrahim has applied for a loan of $800 from Aqroinvest CU to purchase two calves for meat production. The estimated cost for one calf is $400.

loans.use: purchase two calves to expand his micro-business into meat production

loans.name: Vahid

texts.en:
Vahid M. is a 50-year -old car mechanic. He finished engineering at the university and since that time he has worked in the car repair shop. Vahid lives and works in Imishli town, in the southern part of Azerbaijan.

Vahid is married and has 3 children. Most cars in Azerbaijan are Russian brands, but in the last few years, the situation has changed and many people prefer to purchase and drive foreign-made cars. Vahid has to adapt to his customers' demands. Three years ago he had spare parts only for Russian made cars, but he was going to lose his permanent customers because most of them had exchanged their cars for foreign-made ones. So Vahid got training in repairing foreign-made cars and is going to purchase spare parts for foreign-made cars so that he can increase his clientele.

Vahid is considered the best car repairman in the city and so as not to lose his reputation, he has applied for a loan of US$ 900 to purchase new spare parts for foreign cars. That will allow him to better serve his customers.

loans.use: purchase new car spare parts for foreign made cars

loans.name: Shuhratjon

texts.en: Shuhratjon S. is 24 years old and is single.  He lives in Qurgan-tube and has a secondary school education.  Shuhratjon grew up in a big family so he supports his needs by himself. Two years ago he rented a store-front in a Qurgan-tube market and sold coverlets. It was a very profitable business, especially in a wedding season.  As a school starts soon, he has decided to buy school uniforms and equipment.  With a loan of$1000, he is going to buy school uniforms and footwear for low prices. This loan helps to diversify his range of products and locals will be ableto buy school uniforms for a low price.   Shuhratjon plans to pay off the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: to buy school uniforms and footwear for sale

loans.name: Margaret.

texts.en:
Margaret is married and has four children. She lost almost all of her business capital in a transport vehicle accident carrying a variety of articles including animals. The animals destroyed her products and she had to sell them at give-away prices. Since then, she has been barely surviving with her family. Pushed to the wall by these setbacks, she joined GHAPE in April 2007.

Given a loan of $100, Margaret plans to buy plantains, groundnuts, kernel, and chemicals for the sale of foodstuffs and the production of detergents and body lotion. She has always had a ready market as people need detergents in their day to day life for washing clothes, and dishes. 

She plans to repay the loan during the loan term.

loans.use: Sale of food stuffs and production of detergents, and body lotion.

loans.name: Angeline

texts.en:
Angeline Lekunze was born in 1972 and is a single mother of one son. Even though she has one child, she still faces hardship because she was caught up with the responsibility of taking care of her brothers and sisters because her parents are old and unable. In the search for a source of capital to start a business, she contacted GHAPE and became a member in 2002. Since then, she has obtained loans which she has successfully invested and repaid. With these loans, she was able to raise money to pay apprentice fees for her sisters and brothers and save a little.

Given a loan of $1000, Angeline plans to continue farming vegetables and selling puff balls. Her strategy is to sell them hot in the morning periods when many buy them to eat for breakfast. She believes she will succeed more this time because of the continuous training she has gotten from GHAPE in marketing skills and her past experience in this business. The money raised will be used to build and equip her house.

She plans to repay her loan is 24 months. Her first installment repayment will be done on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan

loans.use: Purchase flour, oil, vegetables, foodstuffs, and build and equip house for business

loans.name: Elchin

texts.en:
Elchin H. is a 24-year-old farmer. He is an internally displaced person from the Jabrail region, who fled to the Bilasuvar area in 1993 during the Azerbaijani-Armenian conflict. Bilasuvar is situated in the southern part of Azerbaijan, and Elchin lives there with his parents and grandmother.

He started helping his father in 2004, but later when his father fell ill, young Elchin took over the responsibility for tending their animals. Elchin`s family started their business buying one cow and a calf with money they borrowed from their friends and some money they had been able to save up.

Later, they borrowed US$ 700 from Aqroinvest CU and purchased one milk cow. Elchin repaid all his debts and his farm micro-business is going very well. But because of his father's illness, the money he gets from selling milk products is not enough to improve living conditions for their cattle. Winter is very close and Elchin has applied for a loan of US$ 1200 to build a small shed. He will build the shed himself, because this amount is enough only for purchasing building materials.

loans.use: to purchase building materials to construct a shed for his cattle

loans.name: Tiwara Sylvester

texts.en:
Sylvester is a widower and has four children. The death of his wife in the year 2005 left him alone to cater for the children. His first loan from GHAPE in 2005 was invested in pig farming and the profit he got was used for feeding and education of his children. With a new academic year starting in September, he will be facing a lot of challenges buying books and paying tuition fees for his children. 

Given a loan of $200, Sylvester plans to buy 2 more piglets and 800kg of feed as he already has three bigger pigs which will soon be ready for the market.

He plans to repay the loan within the loan term.

loans.use: Fattening of pigs for sale.

loans.name: Ambang Esther

texts.en:
Esther is married and has six children. Unable to raise  business capital, she found her way to GHAPE in 2004 and received her first loan of $40 which she invested profitably in crop cultivation. With the large size of her family and the increased demand for  foodstuffs in the market, she wants to cultivate more land.

Given a loan of $150, Esther plans to buy cocoyam seeds, groundnut seeds and plantain suckers. She is confident in her activity because she owns the land she is cultivating and it is very fertile as well. 

She plans to repay the loan within the loan ter.

loans.use: Cultivation of cassava, yams and groundnuts

loans.name: Sultan

texts.en:
Sultan M. is a 32-year-old married man who is the owner of a flock of sheep. He is from Khoshchobanli village near Imishli town, which is situated in the southern part of Azerbaijan. Sultan has 2 children. He has seven years' experience in his business.

With money he had saved up, he purchased 6 sheep and 3 goats to raise and sell in 2006. Mutton is in high demand in Azerbaijan, and so his business brought him good income. Autumn and winter are the high season for purchasing mutton, but summer and autumn are also time for wedding parties where much meat is needed. Sultan has decided to borrow US$ 1200 to buy seventeen additional sheep. The estimated cost of one sheep is about $70.

loans.use: purchase 17 sheep to expand his flock

loans.name: Hamil

texts.en:
Hamil A. is a 44-year-old married man who has had his own wood-working studio for six years. Hamil lives with his wife and three children in Sabirabad, situated in the southern part of Azerbaijan. With his first loan of US$ 600 from Aqroinvest CU he opened his studio, and he managed to repay that amount before term. Hamil makes tables, chairs, window frames and doors in his small studio. He is considered an excellent carpenter, and not only in his own town. Every day he gets more than 20 orders from nearby villages and outlying regions.

Increasing prices in Azerbaijan have affected the wood sector also. The number of wood-working studios is increasing and the price for wood is increasing also. In summer it is easier to get wood than in winter. Summertime is also high season for orders from his customers.

The tools Hamil uses for his work are old, so he has applied for a loan of $1200 to purchase new, modern planing tools to make his work easier. The estimated cost for an automated cutter is $600 and he needs other tools as well.

loans.use: purchase a modern planing cutter and other tools

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 36 years old has a small bakery in the Kirkuk market. He has a big family with a poor income. He is applying to get $1200 to purchase a new oven for his bakery. He wants to increase his income and develop his business.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase new oven

loans.name: Hamisi

texts.en:
Hamisi S. is a 35 year old father of two with three dependants. He has a shop where he sells all sorts of bags, ranging from ladies’ handbags, school bags and travelers’ bags. His business is in the Vituka area, a suburb of Dar es Salaam area near the Nyerere International Airport. He has been in this business for the past seven years. He sells both used bags and new bags, and buys stock from wholesalers from Kariokoo, Dar es Salaam’s and perhaps Tanzania’s biggest trading area.

Apart from this business, he also runs a kiosk. He has recently acquired many customers and his goods are in high demand in the area, since he is the only one with such a business in the area. He is requesting a loan of USD$750 to help him buy more stock and accommodate the increasing demand for his goods in the area.

loans.use: Buy more stock to expand business

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 28 years old has a small mini market in Kirkuk. He has two children, both of them in school. He is applying to get $1000 to purchase more goods for the shop. He wants to develop his business and increase his income to enhance his standard of living.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase more goods

loans.name: Claud

texts.en:
Claud is a 30 year old multi-businessman. He is married with two children, all below ten years of age. He is a photographer and runs a photo studio and shop selling cosmetics. He has been a photographer for the past 5 years. Claud gets tenders to shoot weddings and other ceremonies.

He has recently received business training from Youth Self Employment Foundation. He employs one person who together with the wife assist him in the shop. He is in need of USD$550, to help him buy some equipment for his studio and the rest to increase stock in his shop.

loans.use: Buy more stock for the shop and studio

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 28 years old and has a small mobile phone shop in Kirkuk. He will be married next month. He wants to get $1200 to pay for new advertising and to purchase newer and more goods. He wants to increase his income and enhance his standard of living.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: New advertising and to purchase newer and more goods

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria is 26 years old. She is married with 3 children and her husband works as a farmer. Maria makes blouses from blankets, which she embroiders and then sells to the wholesalers offering handicrafts in the city market. She is part of the group Cielo Azul 5 (Blue Heaven 5), together with Josefa Juarez Giron, and Rosa E. Mendez, who also make handicrafts. With the loan, they hope to buy more fabric, as well as thread for the embroidering.

MARIA, tiene 26 años, casada, 3 hijos, su esposo trabaja en el campo como agricultor, Ella se dedica a la artesanía confeccionando blusas de manta las cuales posteriormente borda y vende con los mayoristas que ofrecen artesanías en el mercado de la ciudad.Ella pertenece al grupo Cielo Azul 5 junto con doña Josefa Juárez Girón (artesana)Doña Rosa E. Méndez (artesana) Anastasia Díaz Gómez (artesana). Con el préstamo esperan invertir todas comprando más tela para la confección de sus artesanías y también hilos para bordar.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: Sales of handicrafts

loans.name: Emiliana

texts.es:
Ms. Emiliana C. rents a place since May 3rd in the zone of Villa Nuevo Potosi in the city of La Paz, Bolivia. She is 38 years old and has one son. She has been a client with IMPRO since 1998 and made money with the first loan that IMPRO lent her for her cosmetics business. Currently, she is active in selling clothes like trousers, sweaters and polo shirts. She has found a good market for them, which allows her to have steady and sufficient income for all her needs. The loan she seeks now is to buy more merchandise in larger quantities. That is, by dozens so that it is cheaper and her margins are greater than when she buys merchandise for less (be it by units instead of dozens). Her payment history with IMPRO qualifies her as a “preferred client” as all her previous loans have been paid off in total in installed payments stipulated in each contract. IMPRO suggests giving Ms. C. this new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Emiliana vive en alquiler en la calle 3 de mayo de la zona de Villa Nuevo Potosí de la ciudad de La Paz; ella tiene 38 años de edad y un hijo. Es cliente de Impro desde el año 1998 e hizo su capital con el primer préstamo que se le concedió y su actividad era la venta de cosméticos. En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de ropa como ser pantalones, chompas y poleras, actividad en la que ella ha encontrado un buen mercado, que le permite tener ingresos constantes y suficientes para todas sus necesidades. El crédito que ahora solicita es para comprar mercadería en mayores cantidades, es decir por docenas que es cuando el costo se abarata y sus márgenes de utilidad son mayores que cuando compra mercadería al por menor (o sea por unidades, en vez de comprar por docenas). Su antecedente histórico con Impro la califica como cliente preferencial, pues todos los anteriores créditos han sido cancelados en su totalidad y en los plazos estipulados en cada contrato. IMPRO sugiere concederle este nuevo crédito.

loans.use: purchase clothing in larger quantities

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha works hard to raise and fatten her pigs in which she later on sells them to the people in her community. She is 41 years old and has 3 children and is a member of a group called Agua 1 together with Mrs. Arminda López Bautista (grocery store owner) and Ms. Martha Montoya Díaz who also raises pigs. With this loan, they'll work hard to raise pigs and buy food in great quantities, vitamins and medicines to avoid the fever going around the area and Mrs. Arminda will invest to buy merchandise to stock up her store.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

Martha se dedica a la crianza y engorda de puercos los cuales posteriormente vende entre las gentes de su comunidad, ella tiene 41 años, 3 hijos y pertenece al grupo Agua 1, junto con doña Arminda López Bautista (tienda de abarrotes) y doña Martha Montoya Díaz (crianza de puercos) Con el préstamo las que se dedican a la crianza de puercos compraran comida en grandes cantidades , vitaminas y medicamentos para evitar las pestes tan comunes en la zona y doña Arminda invertirá en comprar mercadería para surtir su tienda con más alimentos.

loans.use: raise and sell pigs

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
N. Florence is married to N. Peter and is a mother of eight children. Given the heavy responsibility of her unemployed husband to provide for the basic needs of her family, she decided to sell foodstuff which was a failure due to lack of capital. She then decided to become a GHAPE member and was trained in business management, marketing techniques, and credit discipline.

Now she is requesting a loan of $100 with which she plans to invest in her former business so she can raise money to pay school fees and buy food for her children. ‘’Buyam Sellam’’ business is a lucrative one as she buys from villages where the prices are lower and sells in urban areas with much profit. She plans to pay off the loan in 15 months.

loans.use: Purchase potatoes, vegetables

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.es:
32 year-old GUADALUPE is seperated and is the mother of 3. She dedicates herself to the sale of grains (beans, coffee, maiz, pumpkin seeds) that she purchases in bulk from the city and sells them at the marketplace outside the city. She is a member of the group Agua 2 along with doña Juana B. Hernández who also sells beans and maiz. Both anticipate investing in the purchase of more merchandise and preparing a location from where to sell their goods.

Translated from Spanish by Christian Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

GUADALUPE, tiene 32 años, 3 hijos, separada se dedica a la venta granos, (fríjol, café, maíz, pepitas de calabazas) que compra con mayoristas de la ciudad y posteriormente lo vende en las afueras del mercado de la ciudad. Pertenece al grupo Agua 2 junto con doña Juana B. Hernández quien también se dedica a la venta de fríjol y maíz Ambas esperan invertir el préstamo comprando más artículos y acondicionar un lugar donde colocar sus productos a la venta.

loans.use:
Traditional Foods Vendor

VENTA DE ALIMENTOS TIPICOS

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es:
The borrower, a divorcée, lives in her own home with her two children on Aspiazu street in the area of Sopocachi in La Paz, Bolivia.  She works in a furniture store for a modest salary. She is still studying and needs to finish her dissertation to graduate in business administration.  The first loan that IMPRO lent her in November 2006 was to organize her documents and papers; this loan was completely paid on time.  The loan she seeks now is to help her finish her thesis, so she can work with more professional ease  and thus, find better paying jobs. Her successful payment history with IMPRO qualifies her as a “preferred client” and her current cash flow gives her solvency for this loan and all the personal needs of her children.

 Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer. 

La señora vive en casa propia con sus dos hijos en la calle Aspiazu de la zona de Sopocachi de la Ciudad de La Paz y esta separada del esposo. Ella trabaja como empleada en una mueblería percibiendo un salario moderado por lo cual ella siguió estudiando ahora solo le falta su tesis de grado para graduarse como administradora de empresas.
El primer crédito que IMPRO le concedió, en Noviembre de 2006, lo utilizo para poner en orden los documentos de su casa; dicho crédito esta totalmente pagado a la fecha.
El crédito que ahora solicita es para terminar su tesis  y poder ejercer su profesión libremente y encontrar mejores trabajos que le permitirán incrementar sus ingresos.

Su antecedente histórico con Impro la califica como cliente preferencial y el flujo de caja actualizado permite ver la solvencia que Gina tiene para pagar dicho préstamo y todas sus necesidades personales y de sus hijos.

loans.use: preparation for her dissertation

loans.name: Ntonifor  Micheal

texts.en:
N. Ntonifor was born in 1942, is married and is a father of three children. After spending almost all of his hard earned savings during the sickness and death of his two children, providing food and other basic needs for his family became a hard rock to crack. He therefore sought the help of GHAPE in 2004 and was trained in business management, marketing techniques, and credit discipline. Since then he successfully invested, managed and repaid loans amounting to $160. With these loans, he was able to buy food and pay school fees for his children.

Given a loan of $500, he plans to sell palm oil and firewood which is the main source of energy in his locality and to use the money raised to expand his business and provide for his family.

He plans to pay off the loan in 18 months and the first installment of repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase firewood, palm oil,

loans.name: Silvia

texts.es:
Silvia buys and sells clothing. She travels to the Guatemalan border to buy clothing and then her niece provides her with a space where she displays the clothing and sells it to people who live in her area. She is 43 years olds, has 6 children and her husband works as a driver for public transportation. She is a member of the microcredit group Agua 2 with Rosa Hernández Sandoval who sells sweets, tacos and empanadas at a public school, and Juana Bautista Montoya who sells fruits and vegetables. With their loan they hope to find spaces to sell their products.

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva Volunteer.

SILVIA, ella se dedica a la compra y venta de ropa, viaja a la frontera con Guatemala a comprar la ropa y posteriormente una sobrina le facilita un local donde exhibe su mercadería y ahí le compran las personas que habitan su localidad. Ella tiene 43 años, 6 hijos, y su esposo trabaja como chofer e la locomoción colectiva. Pertenece al grupo Agua 2 junto con doña Rosa Hernández Sandoval (vende en una escuela pública dulces, tacos empanadas) y doña Juana Bautista Montoya (vende frutas y verduras) Con el préstamo esperan habilitar locales en sus lugares respectivos para poder vender ahí sus productos.

loans.use: Clothing sales

loans.name: Felix

texts.es:
Felix lives in his own home with his five children in a flowery street in the area of Pasankeri in La Paz, Bolivia. He works as a mason in City Hall. It’s been three months he has been separated from his wife and now, he single-handedly takes care of his family. The loan he seeks is to renovate his home so that his children can live more comfortably. IMPRO gave Felix a loan in May 2006 to build a wall in the street where he lives. This loan was completely paid on time. His history with IMPRO qualifies him as a “good client” and is approved for a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

Felix vive en casa propia con sus cinco hijos en la calle florida de la zona de Pasankeri de la Ciudad de La Paz; el trabaja en la alcaldía como albañil. Se separo de su esposa hace tres meses y ahora mantiene solo a su familia. El crédito que solicita es para refaccionar su vivienda para dar comodidad a sus hijos y que puedan vivir mejor. IMPRO concedió un crédito a Felix en Mayo de 2006 para la construcción de un muro para ingresar a linea y nivel en la calle donde vive. Dicho préstamo esta completamente pagado a la fecha. Su antecedente histórico lo califica como buen cliente y puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.

loans.use: Home renovation

loans.name: Mario

texts.es:
Mario owns a car in which he uses to work as a taxi-driver. This car needs repair and some new parts. His home is in the high altitude area of Llojeta Ave, Máx. Fernández Nº 2065, in La Paz, Bolivia. He is married and has five children and owns his home. This is the first time that he seeks a loan. His job qualifies him for this loan since he has experience as a driver and it is his only source of income. The social impact of this loan will be great ,as it will allow Mario to work hard to take care of his family.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Hernandez, Kiva Volunteer.

Mario tiene una movilidad con la cual trabaja como taxista. Dicha movilidad necesita reparación y compra de repuestos. Su domicilio esta ubicado en la zona de alto Llojeta, Av. Máx. Fernández Nº 2065 en la ciudad de La Paz, es casado y tiene cinco hijos y vive en domicilio propio Es la primera vez que solicita un crédito. Su trabajo le permite acceder a este crédito ya que tiene experiencia como chofer y esta es su única fuente de ingresos. El impacto social de este crédito será enorme pues permitirá a Mario continuar con su esfuerzo de mantener a su familia.

loans.use: car maintenance

loans.name: Marcelline

texts.en:
Born in 1971, N. Marceline is married and a mother of four children. Having had no opportunity for secondary education, she was unemployed, and her business of selling cooked food was not moving because of little capital. As a result, she could not pay school fees for her children nor provide them with basic needs. She has also suffered a lot as a result of the loss of her 3 day old baby, the loss of her unborn baby, and a surgical operation. Motivated by these hardships, she joined GHAPE and after being trained in business management, marketing techniques, and credit discipline. She is requesting a first loan of $100.

Given a loan of $100, she plans to invest in the business of selling cooked food. Her business is promising as she sells to early eaters like school children and those in a hurry to get to their job sites. With the profit, she plans to increase her business and pay school fees for her children. She plans to pay off the loan in 15 months.

loans.use: Purchase ground nuts, corn, big pot, grinding machine, and other foodstuff

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Born in 1952, L. Monica is married to a polygamist and is a mother of nine children. Her difficulties in her life time stemmed from the fact that her husband showed more interest to her maids and had little commitment towards her and her children concerning provision of basic needs. This led her to seek help and to become a member of GHAPE where she was trained in business management, marketing techniques, and credit discipline. Since then, she has invested and repaid all of her loans and has been able to raise money to pay school fees and apprentice fees for her children and to buy food for her family.

Given a loan of $800, she plans to cultivate rice, sell and raise money to continue paying her children’s school fees and to increase her business.

She plans to pay off her loan in 18 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Purchase seeds, hire labour, transport

payments.comment: This recent payment was posted in error, we apologize for the confusion. Monica has not yet started repaying her loan, but she will begin next month.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is married and is a mother of seven children and some grand children. She had always wanted to be of the maximum assistance to her loving husband who was found it difficult to meet the demands of his large household. But her attempt to cultivate and sell crops failed because she did not have enough land. She then decided to sell firewood and fatten pigs since less land is needed.

Her search for a start-off capital led her to become a member of GHAPE and before receiving her first loan she was trained in business management, marketing techniques, and credit discipline. Since then, she has been able to invest and repay her first loan of $40 with which she raised money to increase her business and buy food for her household.

Given a loan of $300, she plans to fatten and sell pigs and piglets and also sell firewood which is the cheapest sourced of energy used by 90% of the population. She plans to pay her loan in 15 months.

loans.use: Purchase piglets, pig treatment, firewood

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Born in 1980, Violet B. is a widow with three children who are all in school. She suffers from ill health and emotional stress caused by the death of her husband that left her to singlehandedly take care of her three children. With all of these setbacks, she sought the help of GHAPE and was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline.

Given a loan of $100, she plans to invest in her seamstress job and to open a telephone booth so she can raise money to educate her children. She believes this business will make a profit because she has been trained as a seamstress and she is the only seamstress in her locality. Also, most people communicate now every day through the telephone. She plans to pay the loan in 15 months.

loans.use: Purchase sewing thread, cloth, school books, and pay school fees

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Thirty-four year old N. Charles is married and a father of one child. As a motorcycle driver, he has not been able to raise enough money to provide for his family because of his ill health and his inability to repair and replace old motor cycle parts.

With a first loan of $100, he plans to buy new tires, repair his motorcycle, and buy a new seat for his motorcycle. He believes he will invest and repay the loan successfully in 15 months because a motorcycle is a necessary means of transport in this locality. With the profit, he will provide for his families, buy medications, and save some for future investment.

He plans to pay the loan in 15 months.

loans.use: Purchase tires, new seat, repairs

loans.name: Moses Nji

texts.en:
Born in 1958, Moses Nji is a polygamist married to two wives and is a father of eight children. With a heavy responsibility of having to provide for his wives and his eight children, and given the fact that he is unemployed, he decided to become a member of GHAPE in 1998, where he was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline.

Since then, he has successfully invested and repaid all of his loans with which he raised money to pay school fees for his children, buy a second hand motor bike and buy food for his family.

Given a loan of $1000, he plans to operate a motor bike taxi business. This business is lucrative in this area because it is faster and more convenient on the very poor roads. With this, he can raise money to continue paying his children’s school fees and to provide a capital for his wives.

He plans to pay his loan in 24 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Purchase a motor bike, documents, fuel

loans.name: Magdaline

texts.en:
Sixty-seven year old Magdaline is a widow who has gone through a lot of difficulties in single-handedly providing basic needs for her eight children, and given her old age. Motivated by other GHAPE members in his community, she joined the program where she was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline. Since then, she has invested and repaid all of her loans with which she raised money to pay school fees and provide food for her children.

Given a loan of $600, she plans to sell foodstuff and also cultivate crops so she can raise money to pay school fees for her children and take care of other needs.

She plans to pay her loan in 18 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase corn, rice, cocoyam, garri, seeds, and transport to farm.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica was born in 1965, is married and a mother of five. She is an orphan, having lost both parents when she was young. This deprived her of receiving basic education or any vocational training, hence she was unemployed. To start a business, she sought help and became a member of GHAPE where she was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline. She has been able to invest and repay all of her loans with which she raised money to buy good food for her household, pay fees and buy medication.

Given a loan of $400, she plans to equip her hairdressing salon so as to attract as many clients as possible so she can have enough money to increase the business.

She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

The picture shown here is of Veronica cultivating cassava. This is how she currently brings in income, but she is hoping to use this loan for her other hairdressing business.

loans.use: Purchase of dryer, washing sink, hair rollers, hair products

loans.name: John

texts.en:
N. John was born in 1948. He is married to two wives and is a father of seven children. As a polygamist and the breadwinner of the family, he had difficulties providing the basic needs for his large family. He also lacked the capital to start a business until he came in contact with GHAPE. After receiving training in business management, marketing techniques, and credit discipline, he received a first loan of $30 which he successfully repaid. Since then, he has paid all his loans and has been able to raise money to provide the basic needs for his family.

Given a loan of $800, he plans to fatten and sell pigs and poultry so he can raise money to send his children to school and buy medications.

He plans to pay his loan in 18 months. The first loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Purchase piglets, chicks, vaccines, and animal feed; construct fence

loans.name: Evelyne

texts.en:
Evelyn is a 35 year old mother of two children. She is married to a polygamist, Joseph, and has had a problem of sickness that has resulted into two surgeries. Given the fact that her husband has a heavy responsibility providing for all the other wives and their children, she decided to become a member of GHAPE where she was trained in business management, marketing techniques, and credit discipline. Since then, she has invested and repaid all her loans with which she sold second-hand dresses and she raised money to assist her husband to pay school fees and provide food for her children.

Given a loan of $1000, she plans to sell palm oil and raise money to continue paying her children’s school fees and to increase her business. She will buy palm oil from the villages where they are cheaper and sell in the town so she can make a maximum profit. She will use this profit to pay school fees for her children and to buy food for her family.

She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. Her first loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Purchase of palm oil

loans.name: Mariana

texts.en:
Born in 1960, Mariana M. is married to a polygamist George M. and has five children. The death of her father left her unable to obtain a secondary education and with little commitment from her polygamous husband to provide basic need for his family, she was led to become a GHAPE member; she now is trained in business management, marketing techniques, and credit discipline. Since 2004, she received loans which she succeeded in investing and repaying. The profit raised was used to provide basic family needs like school fees, medication, and clothing.

Given a loan of $400, she plans to continue selling cooked food. Her restaurant is situated in the motor park where there are many customers including passengers and drivers that provide a ready market for her cooked food. She will repay the loan in 24 months and the first installment of repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase rice, cocoyam, potatoes, fish, beans, corn, and okra

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida P. V. weaves the traditional Mayan top called a huipil to provide a little cash for her family. She can weave a huipil in about 15 days and gets about US$100 for it when she sells it at the market. The yarn for a huipil costs her about $30. Before beginning the loan program with Friendship Bridge, Adelaida couldn’t really make much money weaving because she never had enough money to buy the yarn.

Adelaida is 22 and has two young children. She’s committed to getting them into school when the time comes, because she doesn’t want them to have her disadvantage of not knowing how to read, write, or sign her name.

The family lives in a rough wooden house with a dirt floor on a borrowed space. Her husband’s family does have some land, so they get some of the need for corn met that way. Her dream is work together with her husband to be able to buy food and clothing for the kids so that the kids can succeed in school.

Adelaida is a member of the women's group "Flor de Nebaj".

Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Purchase yarn for weaving huipiles

loans.name: Catarina

texts.en:
Catarina M. B. weaves the beautiful huipiles that Mayan women wear all over this part of Guatemala. Her huipiles command the highest prices, because they’re of the highest quality. Unlike women who weave and then have to take their work to a store for resale, Catarina has customers asking for her work and selecting the designs in advance. She gets about US$200 for a huipil, but of course has costs for the yarn; she uses the highest quality. It takes her about 15 days to complete a huipil as long as she can concentrate on it. She´ll use this loan to buy yarn; she normally buys about US$100 worth of yarn at a time. Before having access to the loans she gets through Friendship Bridge she couldn’t really weave much, because she never had the up-front money for the yarn, but now that’s easier to deal with.

Catarina is 30 and has just one child, an 8-year-old who is in first grade. Catarina never went to school and can’t read, write, or sign her name. She had an accident when she was very young and has only partial use of one of her legs. When she was little she didn’t want to go to school because she feared that the larger kids would pick on her.

Catarina´s family has pretty good health, except for the migraines she’s suffered ever since her Caesarian section when her son was born.

Catarina is a member of the women's group "Flor de Nebaj".

Written by Nancy Lews and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Purchase yarn for weaving huipiles

loans.name: Ramona

texts.en:
Ramona U. F. Is a middle aged lady who moved to the Los Alcarrizos section of Santa Domingo, in a community called "Brisal" from a distant location (about 150km away). This community is located approximately 20km north of the city of Santo Domingo (capital of the Dominican Republic). It is a rather densely populated area even though it is in the outskirts of the city. Ramona tells us that she moved here approximately one year and eight months ago. Upon moving, she established their general foods store.

She lives with her husband and two kids in the house that can be seen on the left hand side of the picture. The business which is in the right hand side sells a combination of foodstuffs and alcoholic beverages. In the food area, she sells mostly rice and beans (which is the main composition of the Dominican daily plate), and on the liquor side, she sells beer and rum, both of which are manufactured in the Dominican Republic. "During the weekdays, which are slow food selling days, I normally sell about $60.00 a day. However, during the weekends, we sell almost twice those amounts in a day, although at this time, volume is generated out of alcoholic beverage sales. Most of the product that is sold in terms of food, happens to be rice, and rum on the beverage side. Thus, it is that I want to increase our stock of rice and rum. In doing so, I believe that we can have a better return."

"We sell ice too, and this keeps up the business, as we are known in the neighborhood for our capacity to sell cold beverages. This is an important factor in these days’ hot climate . . . "

loans.use: To increase sales based on the principal products of liquor and rice

loans.name: Muong

texts.en:
Mrs. Muong Y. sells vegetables which she purchases from a wholesaler. Mrs. Muong Y. would like to use the loan to expand her inventory by purchasing more vegetables to sell. She would also like to buy a motorcycle with a cart so that she can transport these additional vegetables between home and the market.

She has a husband (pictured here because Y. was unavailable) who earns $1 a day working as a farmer, and 10 children, one of whom is a garment worker whilst the others work in a paddy.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables and a motorcycle with a cart attached to be used for transporting vegetables.

loans.name: Deanis Altagracia

texts.en: Deanis Altagracia G. wishes to build a full scale beauty center, featuring acrylic nail fixing capacity. Deanis has been living here 3 years with her husband and their three kids. She recently started selling clothing as well, since she needs to complement the income produced by her beauty aids services and products. She also plans to sell some of the clothing that her family in the USA sends her from time to time. "When my husband finishes the construction of the area where I plan to move the "salon" operations, I plan to be able to assist him as he has helped me. I feel very lucky and grateful for all that we have been able to undertake thus far."

loans.use: She wishes to buy  the equipment that is needed to fix the acrylic nails, and wishes to purchase the hair dryer that's  needed in the beauty parlor.

loans.name: Lidia

texts.en:
Lidia C. T. wishes to obtain a loan of $275 to buy clothing in order to make women’s dresses. There is a demand for these dresses in her community.

Lidia lives by herself in this small shed; half of the space is taken up by the area where she does her sewing. Her 3 daughters have now married and live with their family elsewhere. “However, they usually come around here to visit me on a regular basis,” she states. “No one else around this community makes clothing so my business is good!”

Lidia also sells fancy jewelry to complement her income, as there are times when she isn’t doing a sewing job. She’s been a women’s clothing confectioner for over 5 years now, and has done fancy jewelry sales for over 2 years. "It’s a nice combination, as women love to have their clothing matched up with the jewelry they exhibit, so I do just that!” Questioned as to her possibilities in terms of producing and selling men’s clothing and apparel, she states that she can do so, but that as of lately, she hasn’t been asked for this type clothing. However, she mentioned that recently she had done some children’s clothing that she was asked for. She is better known for her women’s clothing design and confection.

loans.use: To buy cloth in order to make women’s dresses

loans.name: Balbina Cornelia

texts.en:
Balbina Cornelia N. has a tough time pronouncing her own name! She has been very productive in the businesses she has started. Her former husband cares for two of her five children, and three of the children are in her care.

This, her latest venture, is a general convenience store. She says that most of her sales are derived from the sale of rum and beer, together with rice. I mentioned that this was the same combination of goods that other merchants were requesting a loan for to sell in the same community. I asked why many women would be stocking the same products to increase sales capability, as opposed to having a different strategy. Balbina mentioned that there are quite a few general stores in the area, but that they all have good businesses. Each and everyone has their customer base already built up, and are sufficiently patronized to bring in a reasonable level of business activity. Many of these businesses, if not all of them, do business not only by selling the products, but also by giving credit to their customers. This is one reason why most of these small entrepreneurs have knowledge of the “financing” art; they do it themselves! It’s a customer retention practice!

loans.use: To buy stock of rice and rum!

loans.name: Mariyanis

texts.en:
Mariyanis has 7 children from 16 years old on down to 5 years old. Estefania, Mariyanis' oldest daughter (16 years old), depicted in this picture, "takes care of business" while her mother completes chores for the family.

Mariyanis is a full fledged businesswoman. She is farming some of the vegetables they sell in the store, right outside of the small shed where they sell the produce. She's had this business for two years now. Additionally, she has some rental property, which she keeps to supplement her income. It is not easy to care for 7 children, one right after the other in age! Mariyanis will use the loan to buy supplies for her store.

loans.use: To buy food, mostly rice, beans, plantain, and other local fruits.

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Mrs. Ven S. is 45 years old and has a husband and one child. Her daughter is a tailor and in order to expand the business, Mrs. Ven S. would like to use the loan to purchase a small shop for her daughter's tailoring business. In the future both daughter and mother would like to expand the business and eventually open a bigger store.

loans.use: To purchase a small shop for her daughter's tailoring business

loans.name: Altagracia Antonia

texts.en:
Altagracia has lived in the town two years now, but has lived nearby for over 35 years. The family consists of 6 members, which includes her husband and 4 children, who all live together.

Pero...don't worry, there's no problem if you have "falta de sueño" (lack of sleep) as she helps her husband with rather unusual ease! Very talkative and articulate, she explains how she's going to buy different types of clothing as she expands her business. She has common markets where she buys her clothing. These markets are all some 20 kms. away from where her business activity takes place. Based on the information she gave us, continuing her clothing sales will benefit Altagracia and her family.

loans.use: To buy men's clothing (mostly pants), and some women's also.

location.town: Jesus Primero community of Los Alcarrizo

loans.name: Hom

texts.en: Mrs. Hom T. is 25 years old and works as a  farmer growing crops on a plantation and she earns $4 a day from this activity. She would like to use a loan to purchase two cows for her rice paddy. Hom T. has a husband who works as an electrician and earns $2.5 every day.

loans.use: To purchase two cows for her rice paddy.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Hom Thorn has paid back this Kiva loan early.

Thank your for your support. Thanks to lenders like you, entrepreneurs around the world have access to low-interest loans to invest into their small businesses and families. We hope that you will continue your support  and reinvest your loan in another entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.en:
Gregoria has 2 children. She used to work in a private house, but then decided to form her own business, which she will start with this loan. She will supply herself with products from Natura International, which sells natural products.

Also, she plans to have her husband, who has a motorcycle that he uses to transport people around the community, collect the revenues that she initially might extend on credit.

We bid her farewell, and expect that this new business will assist the D. R. family in supporting themselves and move out of the poverty they seem to live in now.

loans.use: She wants to buy natural source based medicines to distribute

location.town: Jesus Primero community of Los Alcarrizo

loans.name: Yin

texts.en: Mrs. Yin C. is a 43-year-old widow. She has 4 children, 1 of whom is an electrician. The electrician owns a shop and Mrs. Yin C. would now like to receive this loan in order to expand the shop's inventory.

loans.use: To purchase tools and some equipment for her son's electric shop

loans.name: Qiyas

texts.en: Qiyas M. is 40 years old, married. He was born and lives in the southern Azerbaijani town Imishli. Qiyas owns a store, where he sells bath supplies, laundry powder, soap and shampoos. He started his business in 2000, and, since the business has been going very well, Qiyas decided to expand the variety of products he sells. He has applied for a loan of US$1,200 to make the first bulk purchase of various food products for sale. The estimated total cost of the products he intends to purchase, such as milk, yoghurt, meat products and beverages, is approximatly US$3,500.

loans.use: Expansion of a store for food sales

loans.name: Aslan

texts.en: A. Aslan is 67 years old. He is married and lives in the southern Azerbaijani town Imishli. Aslan has been runing a small food store for the past 15 years. His produce sells so fast that sometimes Aslan has to close the store already after lunch. His daily sales exceed his purchases. Yet, Aslan has 5 children and, to cover all their needs, the store's profit is not sufficient. To increase the revenue, Aslan plans to diversify the products he sells, and is therefore applying for a loan of US$1,200.

loans.use: Expansion of the variety of products sold at a store

loans.name: Anastáncia Nhancuava

texts.pt:
Anastáncia Nhancuavane N. is married and a mother of six children. She lives in Albasine near the city of Maputo. She makes table cloths and bath towels with machine embroidery and also sews clothing. She entered the program on 13 February 2006 with her first loan for 6,000MT. This is her fourth loan cycle. This time she plans to take out a loan for 20,000MT to build a shop where she can sew and display her work. Her business has grown recently with the assistance of two previous loans with which she purchase a computerized embroidery machine. She can now make high quality products for a high-end clientele such as Interfranca and customers in the city of Beira.

Translated from Portuguese by Kiva volunteer Julie Lerch

Anastáncia Nhancuavane N. é casada e mãe de seis filhos. Vive no bairro Albasine arredores da cidade de Maputo. A cliente faz panos de mesa, toalhas de banho, diverssos bordados à máquina e também roupa. Entrou para o programa a 13 de Fevereiro de 2006, tomando como primeiro empréstimo 6.000 MT. Vai para o 4º ciclo de empréstimo e pretende tomar um empréstimo de 20.000MT, o qual pretende aplicar na construção de um estabelecimento para costura e exposição de suas obras. O seu negócio cresceu nos últimos tempos uma vez que com o dinheiro dos anteriores empréstimos conseguiu adquirir uma máquina de bordar computarizada que facilita a realização de obras de grande qualidade e uma clientela de topo como a Interfranca e alguns clientes na cidade da Beira.

loans.use: Construção de Instalações

loans.name: Mary Mankah

texts.en:
Mary is married to Gilbert N. and their union is blessed with eight children. The fact that she was not able to obtain secondary education or vocational training coupled with lack of capital to start a business left her unemployed. This however did not discourage her from trying, so she decided to buy food cheaper from surrounding villages and to sell it in town so she can make a profit.

This motivated her to seek help and she became a member of GHAPE. Before receiving her first loan she was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline. Since then, she has been able to invest and repay all her loans with which she raised money to buy good food for her household, equip her house and increase her business.

Given a further loan of $600, she plans to continue the ‘’buyam sellam business’’ and raise money to pay her children’s school fees and save some with GHAPE. She plans to pay her loan in 18 months. Her first loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Mary would like to buy foodstuff to sell, and pay for transportation and the apprentice fee for her child.

loans.name: Joseph Fru

texts.en:
Born in 1965, Joseph is married to Nguti Grace and is the father of three children. His electrical workshop was burnt during a political uproar which forced him to go to the village to start cultivating crops. This was not lucrative for him to provide education for his children because of lack of investment capital so he was motivated to become a member of GHAPE. Before receiving his first loan, he was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline. Since then, he has been able to invest in cultivating crops and repay all his loans with which he raised money to buy good food for his household, pay school fees, buy medications and increase his business.

Given a loan of $1200, he plans to do motor bike transport business. This is a lucrative business in this area as many now transport themselves on motor bike since it is faster and he has experience in that field. His repayment will commence in the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Joseph would like to purchase a motor bike to provide transportation.

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
Born in 1954, Rachel N. is married to Nji Usmanu and their marriage is blessed with six children. She has faced difficulties in life such as marital problems, health problems and poverty which rendered her unable to feed her family well and assist her unemployed husband to pay the children’s’ school fees. In the face of these challenges, she became a GHAPE member in 2000 and was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline. Since then she was able to invest and repay loans amounting to $1000. With the money raised from these loans, she was able to pay school fees for her children and to construct a house for her family and to pay for rent.

Given a further loan of $1000, she plans to continue selling food stuff in order to raise money to plow back into her business and to continue paying school fees for her children. She plans to pay the loan in 24 months and the first installment of repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Rachel would like to purchase foodstuff (corn, beans, gari, etc.) to sell.

loans.name: Beatrice Lum

texts.en:
Beatrice Lum was born in 1964 and is the mother of seven children. She was abandoned by her husband so she sought for a loan from GHAPE to help her invest in business so she can provide basic needs to her children. Since 2001, she has successfully invested, managed and repaid six loans up to about $800. With these loans, she was able to raise money to educate her children and provide food for her family.

Given a new loan of $1000, she plans to cultivate yams, cassava, and maize, carry out poultry and pig farming and raise money to save and construct her house. She plans to repay the loan in 24 months and the first installment of repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Beatrice would like to purchase chicks, piglets and seeds and till the soil of her farm.

loans.name: Lurdes Eduardo

texts.pt:
Lurdes Eduardo M. is single and does not have any children. She lives in the Marracuene district in Guavea, Maputo Province. She purchases clothing items in South Africa and sells them in Maputo. She delivers the clothing to a group of regular clients and collects payment at the end of each month. She entered the program in February 2006 with an initial loan for 6,000MT. She is on her second loan cycle asking for the same amount which she will use to grow her business. Her business has been growing steadily. In addition to selling clothing she is also now selling products for men.

Translated from Portuguese by Kiva volunteer Julie Lerch

Lurdes Eduardo M. é solteira e não tem filhos. Vive em Guava, distrito de Marracuene na Província de Maputo.Compra roupas na Àfrica do Sul e vende em Maputo, fazendo entregas a clientes fixos e faz a cobrança do dinheiro no final do mês.Entrou no Programa em Fevereiro de 2006 com um empréstimo inicial de 6.000MT. Vai para o 2º ciclo de empréstimo e vai tomar o mesmo valor o qual pretende aplicar no negócio com vista a reforçar o mesmo.o Negócio verificou ligeiro crescimento, uma vez que para além de roupa que vendia anteriormente vende também fatos para homens, os quais faz entregas para trabalhadores em algumas empresas e recolhe os valores no final do mês.

loans.use: Increase stock

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica T. is an orphan who is married and has five children. As an orphan she said it was never easy. But having seen other orphans in positions of responsibility and leadership Veronica states that she then decided to make it in this cruel world. Her constant motivation has been the challenge of providing education, food and medication to her kids, especially as her husband earns very little from his job.

With a loan of $100, she intends to provide her community with beauty products. She intends to buy some hair products and cosmetics that she will sell and use the profit to educate her children and provide basic needs for them. She also plans to increase her business and train apprentices. She plans to repay her loan in 15 months.

loans.use: Veronica would like to purchase hair products and cosmetics for her hair salon.

loans.name: Mary Ngwen

texts.en:
Born in 1975, Mary Ngwen is married to a polygamist, Nde Christain and is the mother of six children. Given the heavy burden on her husband to provide basic needs for her children and those of her maids, she saw the need to start a business of selling tomatoes. However, this business did not succeed because she lacked capital to start off. This led her to seek help from GHAPE and she became a member in 2007. She was trained in business management, marketing techniques, and credit discipline.

Given a loan of $100, she plans to continue in her line of business and raise money to pay school fess and provide food for her children. She plans to pay the loan in 15 months.

loans.use: Mary would like to purchase tomatoes to sell.

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Born in 1948, Julie M. is married and is the mother of seven children. With her husband’s meager salary and her inability to get a job because of lack of education and vocational training, she found a lot of difficulties paying school fees for her seven children. This motivated her to join GHAPE and she obtained a first loan of $30. Since then, she has successfully invested and repaid loans up to $200. With the money raised, she confesses that her children no longer suffer because she can afford their fees.

Given a loan of $1200, she plans to buy a taxi to be driven by her son who has been trained in motor mechanics and driving. Motor taxi is a necessary means of transportation as the majority of the population has no personal cars. She plans to use the profit to continue paying school fees for her children and provide food for the family. She plans to repay the loan in 24 months and the first installment of repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Julie would like to purchase a taxi for her son to drive to make money for the family and pay the children's school fees.

loans.name: Rasim

texts.en: Rasim J. is 51 years old, married, and has two children. He lives in southern Azerbaijani village Alisoltanli, near Saatli region. Rasim opened his small food store in 1996, when he borrowed some money from his friends. In the beginning, the only items he sold were various sweets. The store revenues increased rapidly, and Rasim was able to start selling also cookies, tea and canned products. Even though the store now brings good income to Rasim to cover his family's needs, he would like to expand the variety of goods for sale at the store, and therefore needs a loan of US$1,200 for the purchase of meat and dairy products.

loans.use: Expansion of a food store through the purchase of beverages and meat products for sale

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Born in 1956, Julie S. is married to a polygamist and is the mother of seven children. The problems usually associated with polygamous families led to her mal treatment. She has to work very hard to fend for herself and her children. Motivated by this, she became a GHAPE member in 1998. Before receiving her first loan she was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline. Since 1998, she has been able to invest and repay loans up to $1000 with which she raised money to buy food and to pay school fees and apprentice fees for her children.

Given a loan of $1200, she plans to buy a motor bike and do transportation business. The motor bike will be driven by her son who has experience in the motor bike business. She believes the business will be lucrative as she has been trained by GHAPE in business skills and it is a faster source of transportation especially on poor roads. With this, she will raise money to educate her children in formal and vocational schools. She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Julie would like to purchase a motor bike for her son to start a transportation business to provide for their family.

loans.name: Nely Azarias

texts.pt:
Nely Azarias C. is married and a mother of 4 children. She lives in the Magoanine neighborhood of Maputo. She runs a small store out of her home where she sells basic goods such as oil, potatoes, onions, sugar, etc. She entered the program in February 2006 with an initial loan for 3,000MT. She is in the 3rd loan cycle and is requesting a loan for 10,000MT to increase her product stock. She purchases goods in Swaziland and sells some of them in her store and the rest she delivers directly to some clients and collects payment from them at the end of each month. Her business has shown substantial growth with the application of the previous loans. She has deposited savings above the required amount ain the previous loan cycles.

Translated from Portuguese by Kiva volunteer Julie Lerch

Nely Azarias C. vive maritalmente e é mãe de 4 filhos.Reside no bairro Magoanine em Maputo.Tem uma barraca em casa onde vende produtos de 1ª necessidade como óleo, batata, cebola, açúcar e outros. Entrou no programa em Fevereiro de 2006 com um empréstimo inicial de 3.000MT. Está no 3º Ciclo e vai tomar um empréstimo de 10.000MT para aumento do stock.Faz compras na Swazilândia e parte dos produtos vende-os na barraca e outra parte faz entrega a clientes e cobra no final do mês Tem observado crescimento substancial no negócio uma vez que tem aplicado todo o valor do emprestimo no negócio. Tem depositado Poupanças acima dos montantes obrigatórios em todos os ciclos.

loans.use: Increase stock

loans.name: Ayyub

texts.en: Ayyub B. is 49 years old, married, and has 3 children. Ayyub and his family live in the Khoshchobanli village near Imishli, which is situated in the southern part of Azerbaijan. Ayyub began his business in 2002, when he purchased a cow and started selling milk and yoghurt to the local people. The income from this small business was sufficient when his children were small, but today their expenses have become difficult to cover. To improve his family's living conditions, Ayyub has applied for a loan of US$1,200 from Aqroinvest CU to purchase another cow for US$800 and a calf for US$400 USD.

loans.use: Purchase of a cow and a calf

loans.name: Bih Alian

texts.en:
Bih Alian was born in 1956, is married to a polygamist and the mother of six children. She has suffered from a lot of maltreatment from her polygamous husband who could not provide her and her children with food or pay their school fees. This motivated her to become a member of GHAPE and before receiving her first loan she was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline. Since then, she has been able to invest and repay all loans with which she raised money to pay school fees for her children and to construct her house.

Given a loan of $1200, she plans to sell cooked food and cultivate crops. With this, she will raise money to pay her children’s school fees and apprentice fees, increase her business and build a house for rent. She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Bih Alian would like to purchase seeds and food items to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Born in 1945, Mary S. is married to Chi Moses and they have six children and two grand children. Her wish to see all her children educated was shattered, her husband being unemployed and unable to afford their school fees, talk less of providing other basic needs like food and medication for them. The issue worsened when her daughter died and left her with two grand children to take care of. At this juncture, she sought help from GHAPE and she was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline, which have been reinforced by bi-monthly meetings. She was also given a first loan of $20 with which she carried out crop cultivation, fed her family and sold some food.

Given a loan of $1200, she plans to sell cow meat in the villages hence reducing the distance to be paid by villagers to go to the town market to buy meat. She intends to raise money to buy a plot of land and construct a workshop for her son. She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Mary would like to purchase a cow, rent a shed in the market, buy buckets and a table for her butchery.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Born in 1962, Comfort A. is married and is the mother of nine children. Her source of happiness has always been to see all her children educated. Her husband’s inability to single-handedly pay her children’s school fees motivated her to seek help and she become a member of GHAPE where she was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline. Since then, she has invested and repaid all her loans with which she raised money to assist her husband to pay school fees for her children.

Given a loan of $1000, she plans to sell foodstuffs and raise money to continue paying her children’s school fees and to increase her business. She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Comfort would like to purchase food items, transport to sell and raise money for her children's schooling.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is married to Maracas Ngang and their union is blessed with four children. The fact that she was not able to obtain secondary education nor vocational training coupled with lack of capital to start a business left her unemployed. This motivated her to seek help and she became a member of GHAPE. Before receiving her first loan she was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline. Since then, she has been able to invest and repay all her loans with which she raised money to buy good food for her household, pay school fees, buy medications and increase her business.

Given a loan of $1200, she plans to do motorbike transport business. This is a lucrative business in this area as many now transport themselves on motorbikes since it is faster. The motorbike will be ridden by a trained and experienced driver. With this, she will raise money to pay her children’s school fees and buy medications for herself and her children. She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Esther would like to purchase a motorbike, documents for a motorbike transportation business.

loans.name: Lawrence Ndoh

texts.en:
Lawrence is married to two wives and the father of twelve children. His heart cry is to see his twelve children all established in different jobs so they can be able to take care of him when he is old. To realize this dream, Lawrence has been very hard working, indulging in farming, but has always had low income because he invested little or no capital. Realising the heavy responsibility he has, he decided to join GHAPE so he can get a capital and invest in his crop cultivation business. After being trained in business skills, he received his first loan and has since been able to invest and repay four loans with which he raised money to send his children to school.

Given a loan of $1000, he plans to fatten and sell pigs, then cultivate yam and short-cycle vegetables so he can obtain a profit to continue paying school fees for his children. He plans to pay his loan in 24 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Lawrence would like to purchase seeds and piglets for his farm to support his twelve children's schooling.

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en: Rachel is one of the wives of Anye Samuel and has four children. As a maid to other wives, she has faced problems of misunderstanding with her maids with the husband always showing favor to the younger maids. Also with the little commitment of her husband towards her and her children, she was forced to fend for them. In her search for a capital to start a business she was motivated by other GHAPE members to join them. She became a member and has been able to pay school fees for her children and feed them with the profit made.

loans.use: Rachel would like to purchase a motor bike, documents to raise money to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Born in 1973, Samuel N. has suffered from ill health that resulted from a car accident he had and also from emotional stress after the death of his sister and brother. His parents are unemployed, as is an elder brother, so he has the heavy responsibility of providing basic needs for them as well as younger brothers and sisters. He became a member of GHAPE in 1999 and before receiving his first loan he was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline. Since 1999, he has been able to invest and repay loans up to $1000 with which he raised money to pay school fees and apprentice fees for his siblings.

Given a loan of $1200, he plans to buy piglets to fatten and sell, raise poultry and cultivate yams. With this, he will raise money to increase his business. He plans to pay the loan in 24 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Samuel would like to purchase piglets, pig feed and yam sets.

loans.name: Vazer

texts.en:
Vezir H. lives in Bilasuvar, in the southern part of Azerbaijan. He is 50 years old, married, and has three children. Vezir is an internally displaced person from Jabrail - he fled to Bilasuvar during the Azerbaijan-Armenia conflict. Vezir started his business in 1998 when he borrowed money from Aqroinvest CU for the first time to open a small store.  
At his store, Vezir sells dried fruits and baked goods, as well as laundry powder, soap and shampoos. These products are in very high demand all across Azerbaijan. Particularly after Vezir repaid his first credit, the business has been going very successfully. Now, Vezir would like to enlarge the number of products he sells. He is working very hard and has decided to borrow US$1,200 USD from Aqroinvest CU to purchase dairy products and beverages for sale in the store.

loans.use: Purchase of additional products for sale

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
Born in 1963, C. Rachel is married and has five children. She has faced a lot of challenges as a mother, the worst being the death of her two children in the space of one month.  She has also had an illness that required surgery.  Her husband does not earn a high salary.  Given the need to educate and feed her children, she became a member of GHAPE and was trained in business management, marketing techniques and credit discipline.

Given a loan of $100, she plans to fatten pigs and sell them. She also plans to sell piglets to the community and use the pig droppings as manure on her farm.  She will repay the loan in 15 months. Her first repayment will be made on the date her loan is disbursed.

loans.use: to purchase piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Mrs. Keo Sean is a 54-year-old widow and lives with her single child in a part of Phnom Penh, Cambodia. To supplement her family’s income, Keo Sean is not only employed as a primary school teacher, but she also runs a small tailoring business at home --together, she can typically earn around $2 each day.

In addition, her son works helping his household as a motor-taxi driver. This loan will be used by Keo Sean to purchase a motorcycle for her son and the leftover of the money is to buy thread and some tailoring tools.

loans.use: Needs a motorcycle and some tailoring tools for her business.

payments.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Keo Sarin start and sustain their businesses. Your willingness to share your financial resources has made a difference. We hope you continue to lend through CREDIT in the future. Sincerely, Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Amélia António

texts.pt:
Amélia António M. is 54 years old, single, and a mother of 3 children. She lives in the Luis Cabral neighborhood of Maputo. She is a fashion designer and sews various articles of clothing. She entered the program in November 2006 with an initial loan for 3,000MT. She is in the third loan cycle requesting a loan for 5,000MT to be repaid within 5 months. The amount is to purchase various raw materials such as fabric, thread, zippers, etc. She has deposited savings in each of the previous cycles. It is not easy to determine the growth of her business because she has not been in the program for very long. She has deposited savings above the required amount.

Translated from Potuguese by Kiva volunteer Julie Lerch

Amélia António M., tem 54 anos de idade, é solteira e mãe de 3 filhos. Vive no bairro Luís Cabral em Maputo. É Modista e confecciona roupa diversa.Entrou no programa em Novembro de 2006 tendo tomado 3.000MT no primeiro empréstimo.Vai para o 3º ciclo de empréstimo e pretende tomar 5.000 MT para pagar em 6 meses. O montante é para ser aplicado na compra de diverso material como tecidos, linhas, Zips, etc.Tem depositado as poupanças em todos os ciclos.
